titleStmt.title: Briefing Memorandum From Thomas Tracy Through Richard Kennedy to Walter Stoessel with Attached Iran Guidelines, April 1981
Tracy to Stoessel, 1981

sourceDesc.p: A scan of the original document is available for download (PDF, 183 KB, 5pp.)

p.hi: Source: Department of State, Central Foreign Policy Files, 1981 P-Reels, P810069-1517 through 1521. Tracy’s memorandum to Stoessel received concurrences from Peter Constable (NEA) and, in draft, from JoAnn Dolan (L/ECP), James Roche (S/P), Raymond Seitz (S/S), and Elijah Kelly (S/S-I). The document bears a stamp indicating that Amb. Stoessel saw the memorandum on April 4. The attached declassification review guidelines were drafted by Henry Precht (NEA/IRN) and George Sherman (NEA/P).

body.p: Cited in Toward “Thorough, Accurate, and Reliable”: A History of the Foreign Relations of the United States Series, Chapter 10, Footnote 74

div.head: Briefing Memorandum From Thomas Tracy (Assistant Secretary of State for Administration) Through Richard Kennedy (Under Secretary of State for Management) to Walter Stoessel (Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs)
div.p: Subject: Freedom of Information Requests on Iran

The past two years, and especially the hostage period, have presented unique problems with regard to FOI requests relating to Iran. This was one of the several aspects of the Iran situation in which Mr. Newsom was directly involved. Clearly, some of the political and strategic elements of the problem continue. Given the interest of your office in the past, S/S has suggested that we provide the following brief summary of where we stand and how we got there; and to seek your approval to proceed in a more normal fashion now that our people are free.

Beginning with the first overt action against Embassy Tehran in February 1979, the need was recognized for special care in releasing information relating to Iran in response to FOI and similar public requests. At the same time there was an upsurge in the number of such requests. Many came from journalists. Others came from American companies contemplating litigation or claims against the Iranian Government. Much information on Iran, including some which originated many years earlier, was highly sensitive in these circumstances, reflecting, for example, close US relations with the late Shah and his officials.

After the seizure of the Embassy personnel as hostages, we in practice stopped releasing any information on Iran through the FOI process. We reasoned that almost any official acknowledgement of past US actions in or relating to Iran might in some way be twisted or distorted to the disadvantage of the hostages. FOI requesters affected by this practice were informally notified and appeared to accept the rationale.

The only real exception concerned a request from Newsweek. After the appearance of a series of New Yorker articles which indicated that the author had privileged access to Department information, Newsweek threatened to take the Department to court if its pending FOI request was not processed.

The request concerned the decision to admit that Shah to the United States. CDC, working with L, S/S, and the Iran Working Group, reviewed relevant documents, including Mr. Newsom’s files. With Mr. Christopher’s approval, we released a small number of documents whose contents were already in the public domain.

Since the release of the hostages, NEA, CDC, and L have agreed that the Department must move on the backlog of over 50 Iran FOI cases. These include requests concerning the negotiations leading to the release of the hostages which will incorporate Mr. Christopher’s files; requests for extensive historical material on U.S. relations with Iran compiled by S/P for the White House in September (the “White Paper”), and background documents relevant thereto; and requests relating to sizeable claims by American corporations against Iran. Some of these last will almost surely result in law suits for reasons other than our responses to the requester. They also include Newsweek’s appeal of the documents denied in its request mentioned above. (The New York Times has a similar request on record but has not pressed us.)

On the advice of L, CDC has started reviewing these pending cases, beginning with the earliest. New guidance was sought and received from NEA (copy attached). Retired FSO Charles Naas, now on CDC rolls, heads the Iran FOI review team. He was nominated by NEA for this responsibility and has extensive experience in Iran affairs.

We propose to follow the new NEA guidelines but in every other respect to review FOI cases on Iran henceforth as we do all other FOI requests, which will include consulting with NEA whenever we are in doubt. This will include starting to review two FRUS volumes (1951 and 1952-54) on Iran which have been held in abeyance. NEA, L, and S/P agree.

div.head: Memorandum From Peter Constable (Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs) to Clayton McManaway (Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Classification/Declassification Center)
div.p: Subject: Iran and Freedom of Information

We agree with your memorandum that with the release of the hostages we should take a fresh look at Iran FOI material. While we can obviously be more liberal than our previously very restrictive guidelines, there remain areas of great sensitivity. We hope that your staff can continue to work closely with NEA/IRN in those sensitive areas.

We suggest that recently retired FSO-1 Charles W. Naas be assigned prime responsibility for reviewing all Iran materials. Mr. Naas was deeply involved in Iranian affairs as Country Director and DCM from summer 1974 to summer 1979.
In our view there are four general guidelines that apply to all Iran materials:

list.item: No release of documents that would reveal intelligence sources, methods, plans, or operations;
No release of material that would place in personal jeopardy any American or any friendly Iranian or other national;
A willingness to release documents that illustrate the broad outlines of US policy towards Iran at the particular time;

No release of documents that would seriously complicate efforts to create a new relationship with Iran in the future. We would anticipate that in this crucial area, we would exempt from release material which would compromise the conduct of national defense or foreign policy, as spelled out in FOI regulations.

div.p: In addition, we would like to suggest the following considerations for the specific periods under review:

1951-1955 Documents for FRUS and FOI - A simplified and distorted version of the events of this period has become political dogma in Iran and elsewhere. The release of the full diplomatic record would help to provide a better balance in accounts of our role. For that balance, however, it will be essential to cover our dealings with the British. To exclude the story of US-British cooperation on Iran will not give a true picture of US decisions. We suggest that the Department consult with the FCO to work out practical arrangements for possible release of documents from this record.

1956-February 1979 - Within the general guidelines, we believe we could release much economic, consular, and routine political reporting. There would seem to be very few documents of this sort from this period what could not be released in connection with litigation, but that, as on other subjects, would be decided within the guidelines noted above.

February 1979-November 1979 - Many of the documents held in Embassy Tehran files prior to November 4, 1979, can be considered compromised. Through checking this carefully and keeping in mind the general guidelines, many of these documents could be released.

November 1979-January 1981 - Much, but by no means all, of the diplomatic record for this period has been discussed. We recommend release of documents that conform to the general guidelines and that might help to clarify public understanding of the diplomatic activity to free the hostages.
